job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Coworkers and health insurance and that’s it.
cons: The microbiology department has not been managed well since I started in 2018. It has always been understaffed and the lab would offer pay below market value, so we would have a hard time hiring and retaining staff. They would literally offer prospective employees pay cuts. During the start of the pandemic, the lab operations leadership tried so hard to make sure we did not get Covid pay. Employees had to fight back and go to HR in order to get it. Which took over a year. Our benefits were reduced(no more sick pay, lower differentials, and PTO was reduced), we also have to pay for uniforms and parking. We used to have a flexible start time as long as you were not on a STAT bench, but that was taken away due to it not being “fair” to the other labs. However we are expected to stay hours after our shift if the work isn’t caught up, the other labs do not have this expectation. We get less break time than the other hospitals as well(45 minutes compared to an hour at all the other lab locations) . They keep bringing in more work to the microbiology lab but aren’t being proactive enough when it comes to getting better instruments and benefits to attract employees. Becoming an MLS III has gotten significantly more difficult for no reason for internal employees. However they keep hiring new people as MLS IIIs, including people who aren’t even ASCP/AMT certified. Additionally, non certified employees are making more than certified employees in some cases, which is not right. Lastly, the lab director is not present since they direct multiple labs. I only see them a few times a year. While I understand that, I think we deserve a director that is fully dedicated to just us.

review_title: Avoid the phlebotomy department at all cost
pros: You get to meet nice patients and learn how to do iv starts. You also ger tuition reimbursement. The nurses doctors even house keeping go above and beyond for the patients.
cons:
I am an ex employee who worked there. I used to work in the phlebotomy department. I was treated like trash and so was a lot of other staff members as well.  ( manager)and (coordinator) are liars, unprofessional and need to be fired. I was bullied and harassed for years to the point I had to resign. Even during my resignation period they was doing things to try to get me fired. They was trying to frame Me for things my coworkers did. The coordinator even lied and claimed I threatened her, and the supervisor claimed she called human resources as well and told there manager and when I called human resources, they said they never heard of this. They even bring alcohol to work during Christmas parties. The lead phlebotomist gave us all liquor which Karen dubose and wendy wiley was there and they allowed everyone to drink it. And this was in the 3rd floor conference room.

Bullying exist there as well. I been bullied/and or disrespected by coworkers and management. so many people and cursed out for years and nothing never happened.

The supervisor and coordinator will twist up ur words and make it seem as if I started it even tho I'm the one who reported them. They was hating on my growth because I'm in college to become a nurse, the supervisor underpaid me for years. 

She would give me a 3 to 5 cent raise every year and ive been there for 11 years so u do the matter of how much i was paid. I even was sexually harassed by the supervisor in the microbiology department a few years ago in front of my coworkers and old coordinator. 

The supervisor gonna tell me I'm lying on that manager. They are also falsifying records. They will add things in ur record and claim that they talked to u about things and never did, or the coordinator will write things up and word it as like u are the one who started the bullying when u are the one who called and reported it. She is a liar and a snake.

They will tell all your business out, nothing is confidential. If u have medical problems, or anything they will tell everyone. There is no confidentiality in that department. People even know when someone is about to get fired before it happens.


So many people are quitting in this phlebotomy department left and right because they are being over worked underpaid, disrespected, and they have to service covid patients without covid pay. They even have phlebotomist doing iv starts and no one in the department is certified to be an iv
 technician. 

So many people are afraid to speak out, I used to be scared but not no more. I do not recommend anyone working for that department. You will regret it and dont say I didnt warn u. Management talks about everybody to everybody.

I think god I resigned, without a backup plan, I have a peace of mind and feel protected.

One thing ive learned is not to sign nothing. I used to sign things a lot because I thought if I didnt I would lose my job and I loved working for this hospital. The patients nurses doctors everyone else brighten up my day. U do not have to sign things they give u. Don't let them fool u and tell u, u have to cause u don't. Don't sign nothing that has lies on it thatt manageement atyped up.


Another thing is they was giving us 1 face mask per week to go in patients rooms it took them over a year to give us a box of face masks. And they kept allowing the person who separated continuously sending me in covid rooms because she and her friends didnt want to go

Plus their benefits package other than very reasonable health insurance sucks. Retirement matching doesn't start for 1 year and it was a low match and the match doesn't fully vest for 5 years. review_title: Lots of change but movement is slow
pros: There are a lot of changes going on in the IT organization.  The largest is the consolidation of the applications across a number of hospitals.  This makes for an environment of opportunity and challenges.
cons: Senior management moves very slow on getting the ball moving.  Project managers are left wondering if there will be enough time to meet the deadlines.  IT senior management often does not 'get along' which then is pervasive behavior to levels below.  This makes for a some  what dysfunctional organization.  The organization started as a state organization.  The attitude of 'I have a job and always will' does not promote an environment of getting things done.  You must be able to work through and around these issues to make movement.

pros:
UMMC is a well known research and teaching hospital. Many of the nurses are active with research. The Shock Trauma Center is renowned, in Maryland... The facility encourages nurses to continue with their education. 
The employer's benefits, tuition reimbursement, and paid holidays are comparable to other hospitals in the area.
You can walk to the Inner Harbor and can stay in a hotel, within walking distance, during snowstorms! :)
cons:
Be aware, this is an inner city hospital--There are muggings and drug deals going down a few blocks away. 
The salary is lower than most and the employee cost for benefits is going up, both out of pocket AND out of your check. 
Upper management isn't visible and the blatant favouritism with the cliques within unit-based leadership makes it challenging to work day to day. 
That being said, it's a great stepping stone for your career.

My first experience working in a hospital, overall, has been mediocre flavored with a bit of concern of what it will be like once I graduate nursing school.

review_title: Although the job wasn't for me, there are inherent flaws in which prevent it from being an objectively better job.
pros:
University of Maryland Medical Center (UMMC) is certainly a prestigious place for an occupational therapist to work. UMMC itself is an expanse base of knowledge that will sharpen your evaluation skills and knowledge base as a therapist; what you garner from this specific job will bolster your skills for other jobs (in some capacity - more on this later). 

Productivity is a non-issue: despite patients routinely leaving the floor, being medically held, or refusing, the minimum requirement for 6 patients a day (for as much as one unit a piece if you desire) is perhaps the least intense you will find in any therapy job. 

Directorship (and the respective Rehab Managers for hospital and pediatrics) is superb and inspiring in both words and action.
cons:
Despite very honest effort, an occupational therapist in a hospital as large and celebratory of their RNs and MDs is largely decorative at best, and is often mistaken for PT. The medical expectation is that job is to move the patient to the chair (or to the bed), and you will often be pressured into fulfilling your singular role - many patients can withstand little else physiologically. 

Worse yet, however, is politics at the floor management and clinician level. As rehab "tribes" are sectored by territory in the hospital, it is uncomfortably clic-like to the point where it can be easy to feel segregated (I did not experience this problem to full severity and some of my co workers were the most warm, welcoming, and understanding I have seen in my career; I did see this segregation towards others, however). Furthermore, there are horror stories of many experienced floor managers being unfairly selective and catty towards allowing perfectly eligible and eager staff to promote - it's a matter of being liked moreso than being capable. 

The pay, frankly, is not very good. You will start at $58,200; with taxes and benefits out, this is essentially $3000 a month. UMMC competitor Medstar offers thousands more for starters for the same work...and full time jobs outside of the Acute Hospital arena will start you $75,000 as a new grad ($81,000 for a certain facility associated with Lifebridge), and more if you have more experience (or a silver tongue). You may have to work somewhat harder for the money, but in the end, you're committing the same amount of time to each company per week.

review_title: Great learning experience but stagnant salary with little hope of improvement
pros: Excellent learning experience - you get terrific exposure to high acuity, medically challenging patients. The multidisciplinary focused patient care allows you to liaise with physicians from multiple specialties, respiratory therapists, physical therapists, occupational therapists, dietitians, nurses, social workers, etc. Everyone is very generous with their knowledge and takes time to educate you. Generally speaking (there are always exceptions, of course!) everyone is very supportive and team focused to get the best done for the patients. All in all this is an excellent hospital for patients and I would not hesitate to recommend it to any family member or friend.
cons: Our salaries have been basically frozen (exception being the rare 1% raise) for years (since 2009) but our costs (healthcare, parking, taxes) have continued to go up. Just this May the hospital decided to increase nursing salaries to be more competitive (market rate for the area) but the increase is honestly, too little too late. To add insult to injury the hospital offers nurses from outside institutions with the same experience / skill level more money than their current staff (offensive) to attract them but tells us we are paid the market rate (not true). I know this for a fact from 2 friends who told me what they were offered (and they turned it down because although more than what we make it was still LESS than they were making across town at the competitor!!). This makes it difficult to want to climb the ladder - you feel you will get cheated the whole way up. They DO NOT offer more money for having a BSN (or other advanced degree), doing charge, precepting, having CCRN.

pros:
The people that work here enjoy working here and make your day to day duties better.  Everyone is friendly and communicates with each other.

Opportunities to expand in your career are good.  While this doesnt necessarily mean promotion, the opportunity to learn more is offered through tuition reimbursement, committees, and interactions.

Great commuting choices.  Public transport and parking are easy.

Work/Life balance.

review_title: Help Desk Management needs to be replaced.
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Columbia, MD
pros: The company and all other IT teams are a great team. Benefits are good. The chance to advance to other departments exists but is held up by the management of Help Desk.
cons:
These are the complaints from the Help Desk on a routine basis. Employees on both evening and overnight shift are required to work alone 2 of the 5 days they are scheduled to work. Policy states we are not permitted to go “Not Ready” at any time as this would leave helpdesk phone unattended and thus leaving all calls received during our scheduled meal break and rest breaks unanswered. We are placed in a position where even going to the lavatory is frowned upon and we are questioned to our whereabouts either verbally or via email if we were to place ourselves in the “Not Ready” status. We do not receive compensation for the 30 minutes which is automatically deducted from our Kronos Time Swipe . Additionally, we are not permitted to use the “cancel meal deduction” as we have been advised that it is just the way it is when you work on evening or overnights due to scheduling issues. The fact we will not be able to take a meal break is a known fact as they only schedule one person and we are not permitted to take an uninterrupted break without placing all seven hospitals and any subsidiaries we support in the position of not having immediate response to critical IT issues. Employees have attempted in the past to adhere to the Human Resource policy of submitting Kronos forms and the employees were advised that this was not the helpdesk procedure. They were not honored or processed

Although we "earn" sick time we are not permitted to take more than 4 days within a calendar year (this is not HR policy - this is the policy of the help desk) We have had numerous employees report to work quite ill as they cannot afford to be written up for sick time taken and this has caused viruses and flu to infect others. On other occasions it has been said that if you need to schedule surgery or attend a child’s surgery you are not permitted to take more than 4 days per year without a written occurrence and you would need to use vacation time instead. We have also had an employee who received a phone call stating they had to take a family member to the hospital for an emergency situation. They advised management of issue and were given permission by one member of management to leave and then upon return to the workplace received a reprimand up by another member of management. Another employee received a call from their spouse regarding their child being quite ill and when the employee asked permission to leave they were told no and that they would be written up and possibly terminated if they were to leave.

Time earned - although we earn PL days and if working a holiday are entitled to an alternate day off, since the turnover is so rampant and the implementation of a new program prohibited us from scheduling any leave from October to December all employees were forced to surrender the time earned, they just do not have the people to cover the shifts.

There appears to be a very evident racial disparity and certain demographics are all but forced off the help desk. 

An employee with a disability once asked for a larger monitor and was denied as it was "not in the budget" - She very soon after became a former employee. 

Profanity is used by management when they speak to staff, belittling and verbal abuse is commonplace. 

All other departments are aware of situation but nothing is being done.
